want to show you it on the chart quickly so first things first we have moving averages we have a long-term moving average which is the 200 or the 150 then we kind of have a mid longterm which is like a 50-day and then two shorter term moving averages a 21 and a 9 these numbers change slightly you can Tinker with different variations as you could tell I tend to move between these the 50 is almost always on the chart and then these sometimes change sometimes I use an 11 sometimes I use a seven sometimes I use 22 instead of 21 you can play with these numbers a little bit it doesn't make that big of a difference these are what I found to generally work and there's a handful of things that matter to me as I'm looking through these but I want to really emphasize this point to you as we go through all of these different indicators there are a handful of traits that I'm going to apply the first is multiple time frames so I'm not going to look at moving averages just in a vacuum I'm going to look at them across different time frames just like all of these it helps me gain context first and then Precision scale velocity durations the relationships all of these things matter to me so I'm not just looking at the moving averages and saying oh here is a 9-day moving average below the

across different time frames just like all of these it helps me gain context first and then Precision scale velocity durations the relationships all of these things matter to me so I'm not just looking at the moving averages and saying oh here is a 9-day moving average below the 21-day I'm looking at what's the width between these two what's that relationship doing what's the steepness of these moving averages understanding how they behave so for example 9-day moving averages they're going to move pretty voraciously because it's not using a lot of data however if we look at something like a 200 day moving average notice how it doesn't really move quite that much but then when I see it picking up this kind of slope this is massive in relation to how this moving average typically looks so part of is you have to develop a relationship with the different tools you use so for me I'm going to use moving averages across those time frames I'm looking for the width between them that indicates strength just as slope how steep is the slope I'm looking for orientation is the 9 above the 21 above the 50 above the 200 with price above the M if that's the case that's pretty dang bullish in terms of moving averages then you can take a look at short-term crossovers like the 9 below the 21 or the 9 above the 21 you can see how that all looks in

above the 200 with price above the M if that's the case that's pretty dang bullish in terms of moving averages then you can take a look at short-term crossovers like the 9 below the 21 or the 9 above the 21 you can see how that all looks in relation to longer term moving averages all of these things matter now I'll leave you to Tinker with this to find specifics that work for you but for me I really want to understand what the slope is what the relationship is between them and where is price in relation to them that really matters to me and then depending on the duration of the trade I use different crossovers for different things because if you'll notice if you use let's say for example a 50-day cross in below the 200 day that's going to be a much slower indicator because there's a lot more data integrated into it if you're trading a really short-term strategy this might not align well with you so you have to figure out what time frames matter most for the individual strategy you're applying next up linear aggression channels 50 and 100 so these are the kind of these gray lines in the background this gray line here is the 50 this one is the 100 the 50 encompasses 50 of the moves on the chart in the aggregation period the 100 encompasses 100 of them you can view these kind of like standard

are the kind of these gray lines in the background this gray line here is the 50 this one is the 100 the 50 encompasses 50 of the moves on the chart in the aggregation period the 100 encompasses 100 of them you can view these kind of like standard deviation Channels with this being a plus one - one plus 2 -2 it's not perfect slight difference but it typically will operate so I'm looking at two things primarily the first thing what is the trend are we positive sloping are we flats are we negative sloping so as I look at iwm on a one-year daily this is positive sloping maybe if we come into a six-month daily we see it still positively sloping then if we come into a 3-month daily we see it negatively sloping so you can see as you look at different time frames you're going to see slight different things the first one I'm looking for is the overall direction the second thing I'm looking for is price extension most price is going to fall within this inner band the 50 band when I see price starting to get strung out to these outsides it can tell me that we're looking a bit overextended does it mean that it can't go past it further no it certainly can but I'm looking at technical analysis in terms of probabilistic outcomes so if I see something hovering near an extreme I tend to think we

outsides it can tell me that we're looking a bit overextended does it mean that it can't go past it further no it certainly can but I'm looking at technical analysis in terms of probabilistic outcomes so if I see something hovering near an extreme I tend to think we might see some sort of reversion provided that we see other support for it so in this case linear aggression channel is upward sloping however we get up near a plus two linear aggression Channel which is near-term resistance price balls flow the 99 day moving average and so on and so forth so you can kind of paint a picture for yourself now back to moving averages really quick in terms of simple moving averages exponential moving averages volume weighted moving averages you can Tinker with all of them I I've studied all of these in depth and I genuinely do not think think there's a giant difference between them I think it doesn't matter what I like to do is for the short-term moving averages I use Simple moving averages because they already have enough sensitivity to current price and for the longer term moving averages I like to use exponentials sometimes because it helps me become a little more sensitive to current prices with the longer term moving average again you could use SMA for all of them so Mas linear regression channels next we have volume profile average volume if you'll recall the two things we

resistance there because there's a lot of people that might be wanting to get out that bought here they have a chance to get out for a scratch and they might want to exit the trade the other thing I use them for is kind of these shelves these nodes so you notice how when price fell below the point of control notice how there's no gray area here that tells me that there was not a lot of transactions at this point and notice how easily price fell below until it started getting to these other nodes and now price is starting to congest out again so when you see nodes like this it just means that again there's people willing to transact there and when you look at these big gaps those to me look like areas that we can move quickly around whether it's up through them to the bullish side whether it's down below them and again it's really important to look at different time frames because if we look at a one-year daily this note is still there it's just not the point of control the point of control is actually down here and if you'll notice price happened to bounce right around it so this tells me that there there's a lot of people willing to buy here and again on both of those two time frames we looked at there's a big gap here there's not a lot of people transacting at that

you'll notice price happened to bounce right around it so this tells me that there there's a lot of people willing to buy here and again on both of those two time frames we looked at there's a big gap here there's not a lot of people transacting at that price so that just kind of doubles down that thesis that we might see movement quickly through this Zone where there's not a lot of transactions occurring Now volume average is really just for context and it helps me understand breakouts and breakdowns the thing to know about price is that it can fall under its own weight it doesn't need a lot of transactions to fall fast in order to raise and kind of bounce through resistance or to have an extended up move it needs outsized volume so what I like to do is use a volume average this purple line is a 30-day volume average and you can see I'm wanting to use kind of a shorter term time frame which is 30 days you can use longer term 50 days depending on you know the duration that you're looking to trade but I'm looking for anomalies I want to see periods where if we're rallying and volume is really low like this case here I'm I don't really trust that that much that's really what what that means to me if we're rallying and we see outsized volume like this I'm more interested especially if there's

transactions an oscillator this is like a secondary indicator for me so I use the money flow index or volume weighted moving average convergence Divergence the money flow index is kind of like a volume weighted RSI but you can use it to help with pinpoint timing things like that the main thing I would talk to you about using these is one seeing if they're flattening out and if if price starts to flatten out Beyond it that's interesting to me I also am interested not so much if it gets overextended undere extended I'm less concerned with that but if there's Divergence so if price is rallying and this is going down that tells me that the rally is suspicious or if we see price starting to shoot up and out and this was negative trending for a while that tells me that I would expect this to start turning up and if it doesn't again I would be suspicious so it's just kind of like a tertiary indicator to me breath allows me to look at the market as a whole so slightly different than all these ta tools breath like net highs and lows that gives me a sense of the total market and net highs and lows is down here so this is looking for the New York Stock Exchange and it's telling me exactly that net highs and lows how many stocks are making highs compared to those to those making lows and typically

Direction open up an Excel sheet list out a bunch of random stocks apply your technical analysis in the columns list out the different analysis you're performing with the different moving averages if you're using volume profile so on and so forth and then at the end list out whether or not you're bullish bearish or you're neutral and then track how you do that will help you so much with identifying what works and what doesn't work for your specific style of trading it's massive cannot emphasize that enough so the next video we're going to go into the actual process how I put all of this together to look at things efficiently with a pretty high degree of accuracy as always if there's any questions throw them in the show notes below and I'm happy to take a look I try to answer all of them when they pop up if there's anything I left out also let me know don't forget to like subscribe share the video so we can get some more views on these things huh and uh be an outlier and see you guys later
